_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1.0    ACCIDENTAL RELEASE AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES



KIK Custom Products, Inc. (KIK) (formerly CCL Custom Manufacturing, Inc.) owns and operates a facility in Danville, Illinois which is subject to U.S. EPA regulations governing Accidental Release Prevention Requirements:  Risk Management Programs (RMP) under Section 112(r) of the Clean Air Act (40 CFR Part 68).  This Risk Management Plan has been developed in accordance with the requirements specified under 40 CFR part 68, Subpart G.  The Risk Management Plan certifies that KIK has instituted a Risk Management Program at the Danville, Illinois facility that is in compliance with U.S. EPA RMP requirements.



The Risk Management Plan follows the format provided by the RMP Data Elements published by U.S. EPA.  In addition to identifying the applicable corporate policies and risk management systems, including comprehensive accident prevention and emergency response programs, the Risk Management Plan identifies a set of worst case and alternative release scenarios and summarizes the facilityA?s five-year accidental release history.  The Risk Management Plan also verifies that prevention program and emergency response plans are appropriately designed to minimize risks to workers and the potentially affected public.



KIK initially submitted a Risk Management Plan in June 1999.  Under 40 CFR 68, Risk Management Plans must be updated at least once every five years. This document presents the updated Risk Management Plan for KIKA's Danville manufacturing facility.



1.1    Corporate Statement



KIK Custom Products recognizes and believes in the importance of safeguarding both our natural resources and our environmental heritage.  As such, we are committed to our customers, employees, and the various communities in which we operate to protect the health of our environment through the development and maintenance of programs which:



- Comply with federal, state, provincial, and local environmental and occupational heal

th and safety legislation.

- Audit compliance with legislative and company standards, identify long-term potential liabilities, and take appropriate action.

- Minimize environmental health and safety risks to our employees and the communities in which we operate through the use of safe operating procedures, emergency plans, and employee training.

- Conserve natural resources, minimize the generation and discharge of waste, and ensure that any hazardous waste disposal is handled in a safe and socially responsible manner.

- Integrate the A?4RA? principlesA?reduction, reuse, recycling, recoveryA?whenever possible.

- Support customers and suppliers in the development of alternate products and packaging.

- Support efforts to educate consumers and government regarding the environmental impact of our products.

- Promote responsible legislation concerning our products and our industries.

- Identify and deal appropriately with potential environmental risks and liabilities associated with any acquisition, divestiture or discontinuance of operations.



1.2    Risk Management System



KIKA's Danville facility has developed a management system to oversee the implementation of the Risk Management Program in accordance with the requirements of 40 CFR Part 68, Subpart G.  



2.0    PROCESSES AND SUBSTANCES SUBJECT TO 40 CFR 68



The EPA Risk Management regulation identifies three levels of requirements for industrial processes.  Program 1 can be applied to any process which has not had a A?significantA? release of a regulated substance over the previous five years and for which the worst-case release does not affect A?public receptorsA? (e.g., residences, parks and recreation areas, commercial/industrial facilities, hospitals).  Program 2 apples to any process that is ineligible for program 1 and is not subject to Program 3.  Program 3 apples to processes that are subject to the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) standard.  Th

e KIK Accident Prevention Program elements are adopted directly from the compliance program for the PSM standard, consistent with Level 3 RMP Program requirements for this KIK facility under 40 CFR 68.  Program 3 related information is included in the Data Elements section in Appendix A of the Risk Management Plan.



2.1    Program 3 Process



The KIK Custom Products plant in Danville produces various consumer aerosol consumer products for major marketers.  These aerosol products contain various amounts of flammable hydrocarbon propellants to provide the pressure to force the product from the container.  Five flammable chemicals are stored at or above the threshold amounts for regulated substances.  These include isobutane, n-butane, propane, 1,1-difluoroethane, isopentane and dimethyl ether (DME).



Hydrocarbon propellant is delivered to KIK by railcar or truck, transferred to dedicated pressure tanks located in the tank farm and, when needed, piped through a central manifold to the propellant charging rooms.  Because of the high volatility and flammability of the propellants, all filling operations are conducted in an isolated, specially designed propellant charging room.  These rooms, the high speed filling equipment, and the auxiliary equipment contained therein are designed according to stringent safety codes to guarantee that explosive concentrations of propellant do not occur.  High volume ventilation, organic vapor detection, ultraviolet spark detection and halon suppression equipment are a few of the standard installations.  Typical rooms contain:  welded piping, air opened/spring-closed remotely and manually operated ball valves, heat exchangers, flow, temperature, and concentration sensors and exhaust air plenums.  Each propellant charging room is also equipped with an explosion relief panel.  



The atmosphere within each room is constantly removed and directed out one or more exhaust stacks.  The concentration of propellant within each room is continuo

usly monitored at the ductA?s collection plenum near the floor.  When the concentration within the room is less than 20 percent of the lower explosive limit (LEL), the room is ventilated by at least one and one-half air changes per minute.  When the concentration reaches 20 percent of the LEL, high-speed fans automatically activate to ventilate the room more quickly at more than three air changes per minute to decrease the propellant concentration.  If the percentage of LEL exceeds 40, the production filling operation and associated equipment is automatically shut down.



Propellant is transferred from the tank farm at its equilibrium pressure at the liquid temperature.  To achieve the significant pressure differential required to facilitate high-speed, efficient filling, the pressure of the propellant must be raised to between 600 and 800 psig.  These pressures are obtained through the use of A?pressure boosterA? pumps.  At KIK, these pumps are located outside each gassing room.  The propellant is then piped to the rotary filling machines in the gassing room.  A recirculation loop handles excess propellant and can accommodate higher recirculation rates depending on the filing machineA?s demand.  The recirculated propellant may be water-cooled or steam-heated as necessary.



RMP regulations require that each facility complete a worst-case and an alternative case release scenario for Program 3 processes.  Since all five of the chemicals are flammables, one chemical can be used to represent the impacts of any of the flammables.  The worst-case release scenario for flammable gases is defined as a release of all the contents of a butane tank car.  A single alternative release scenario addressing all flammable substances as a class must be one that is more likely to occur than the worst-case scenario and that reaches an endpoint off-site, unless no such scenario exists.  The selected alternative release scenario is a release resulting from damage to a 2-inch relief val

lanning and Response; and

- Compliance Audits.

 

4.0    FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



In conjunction with the current RMP and PSM programs in place at the KIK Danville facility, there is a standard management practice that requires immediate internal reporting of unusual events, including those in which any abnormal emission of regulated chemicals is observed or suspected.  The incident information is reviewed by supervisory staff and a determination is made as to whether a reportable quantity of any chemical listed as requiring reports to regulatory authorities is involved.  If so, the appropriate authorities are notified.



During the past five years, KIK Custom Products has not had a release of regulated flammable substances from the Danville facility that has caused onsite or offsite injuries, emergency response, offsite evacuations, or damage to property or the environment.  

 

5.0    EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



KIKA?s Danville plant has established an Emergency Action Plan (EAP) to ensure appropriate steps are taken to protect public health and the environment, as well as the safety of plant employees.  The EAP is designed to address foreseeable emergency situations at the facility and provide appropriate hazard and emergency preparedness information to employees, contractors, emergency response personnel, and the community.  Emergency situations can include fire, explosion, chemical release or spill, bomb threats, weather emergencies, site security (i.e., terrorism) and other natural emergencies.



KIK has developed procedures to be followed in the event of an emergency and a command structure to evaluate an emergency to determine the appropriate action to be taken to remedy it.  KIK staff has a first responseA? capability and are able to administer basic first aid and CPR.  KIK will rely on the Westville Area Fire Department and the Vermillion County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) for assistance in controlling emergency releases and extinguishi

ng fires.

 

6.0    PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



KIK is committed through its grass-roots Continuous Improvement process to the expansion and refinement of its safety programs with special emphasis on training.  KIK facilities maintain active safety committees with broad involvement in training, incident investigation, and auditing.  These efforts are supplemented by a Divisional Auditing Program for general and critical safety.  KIK utilizes external professional resources to validate its internal programs and activities.  KIK also maintains strong contact with local fire and emergency management agencies, participating in mock disaster training exercises.
